review_title: Staff members love God deeply but burn-out increasingly common
pros:
-Wise, wonderful co-workers who feel like family
-Flexible hours
-Leaders are transparent and love God
-Increasing cultural awareness, and willingness to engage in complex issues such as ethnic identity, gender equality, etc. 
-At it's core, "Win, Build, Send" is a solid philosophy of ministry. I have some disagreements with the way Cru goes about this (especially in recent years), but I still think their core vision and mission is good, beautiful and true.
cons:
-Decreasing opportunities to connect with co-workers
-Difficult to maintain work-life balance
-This is a VERY low structure job: expect loose hours, lots of independent work, a revolving door of teammates and lack of clarity over your job description. 
-The organization is still reeling after some major structural changes over the past two years. They will need to figure out how to care for employees in the midst of this, or they will continue to lose staff. 
-Culture of doing and producing programs is very prevalent. Staff burn-out quickly due to lack of practical value for things such as slowness, spiritual formation, silence and solitude, sabbath, therapy, and mental health issues. 
-Lack of new ministry philosophy for how to engage Generation Z. As campus ministers trying to reach this generation, I'm not sure why we aren't talking about this.

pros: Great to work for and depends on team you are on

pros:
Flexible Work Schedule

Travel opportunities
cons:
Honestly, working for CRU was kind of like working for a cult. There’s a bunch of smiling, happy, well dressed people from the outside. But, once you scratch the surface or be a little different, you start to see the organization’s true nature. 

1.) The staff are generally unprofessional. Most staff have been recruited straight from college and many have never had professional employment elsewhere. There is a naive attitude towards reaching objectives and organization. 

2.) Critical thinking and strategic planning is generally looked down upon. By default, Christian ministries tend to attract people that value feelings more than objective analysis. While this value system works for connecting with people, it is not effective when engaging in strategic planning or evaluating tactics. I found myself fairly judged and treated wrong whenever I engaged in honest critical analysis of our methods. 

3.) If you’re life isn’t already filled with other CRU staffers, it soon will be. This means that your social, spiritual, familial, social, etc spheres will be absorbed into the CRU bubble. This is perhaps the biggest danger. Once in this bubble, you’re ability to think independently is held hostage to the various relational pressures you’ll have from the CRU bubble. It’s like living in Jonestown. Everyone drinks the same kool aid all the time. If you don’t drink the kool aid, you’re thought of as “disobedient” or “sinful” or “immature.” Criticize Bill Bright or the 4 Spiritual Laws and you’re definitely a goner.

Organizational leaders are empathetic, committed to fruitful work and continuous improvement, which translates to a willingness to make difficult decisions that further the mission and promote overall health for staff. 

Coworkers are family mindset. Flexibility for family values, and willingness to work together with staff to find the best job fit. Genuine care for internal and external stakeholders.
cons:
Currently in the process of opening up career pathways for diversity in leadership, but there's still a ways to go.
While there is a great heart to help foster growth and development among staff, it can be difficult to address and deal with underperforming individuals.

review_title: Changed the World but got left in the dust
pros: Cru is amazing on vision. At Cru I have literal had the chance to change the world on some of the projects I have worked on. Most people you work with end up being strong Christians who care about each other a lot.
cons:
Often when those amazing individuals who care well one-on-one get together to make decisions they forget the values of the organization; caring a lot more about goals/tasks/projects than they do about people. I have found this to be true of several areas of Cru but particularly Operations.

Also, with high vision often comes a disconnect with reality. I am often asked to work too hard to achieve the impossible. It always seems very spiritual but often it comes down to poor planning by management.

Cru is a great organization to work for, I have enjoyed most of my time here but my advice is to be careful about boundaries. Very few people are going to help you with boundaries and sometimes won't respect them when you apply them.

review_title: Two levels of employees - and it makes a difference

The benefits for supported staff are superior to paid staff.  Paid staff must sign a document saying they are adhering to the organization's moral standards which are relatively strict, as would be expected of a religious organization.  The organization raises a lot of money but most of it is used to pay the salaries of supported staff, who are compensated as missionaries on a relatively meager scale.  The organization continues to pay supported staff even though they are not sure what they do or even where they are.  This is not ethical and does not honor the donor who is supporting the staff member.

review_title: Great organization committed to its mission and people
pros:
Cru (formerly Campus Crusade for Christ) is strongly committed to its core mission of being a "caring community passionate about connecting others to Jesus". The leadership typically invests a lot of energy in developing people and making sure people are doing well.

Most of the staff members raise their own support meaning they develop and cultivate a team of donors that pays their salary. The pro to that is that you have strong job security and an ability to really focus on the mission and vision and how you can best contribute and not on pleasing your boss to try to get a raise or a bonus.

There is something really cool about your daily work lining up so closely to your core values as a believer in Christ and working for Cru really offers there. There are a lot of exciting and unique opportunities to serve overseas and attend conferences and trainings as well.
cons:
One con is that if you are a full time staff all of your income (minus rental properties and stocks) needs to come from donations through Cru which means that you can't participate in side projects for profit. Another challenge can be that certain conferences are required to attend and so you need to arrange vacation around those. Also, being in full time ministry can have emotional and spiritual challenges as well - it can be tempting to hide your real struggles to save face as a "professional Christian".

But if God is calling you to Cru he will provide for you and equip you for the service!

+ you work on the school calendar so summers can be fun
+ generally speaking (there are horror stories) your teammates are energetic, fun, and passionate people.  It can be a real fun time
+ the leadership training is really remarkable, much more than you should expect in other early career positions

- compensation is a BIG problem.  you raise your own support.  if you are outgoing, well connected to money, went to a school with people who will get good jobs, etc... then you are positioned to make good money.  if you are not, then you will struggle miserably.  many times on one team there are people who do the same job and have much different take home pay because one is connected and the other (maybe a minority person, maybe someone from a not-wealthy-denomination) will take home 1/2.
- Campus Crusade for Conferences.  It is no joke.  Massive waste of staff time and donor dollars
- The culture is Old School.  The organization leaders talk a big game about being relevant, culture, new methods and the University as a center of ideas.  However, change is slow.  It is humorous that an effort to get rid of "Crusade", which brings images of Christians behaving badly (barbarously), the organization labored over a brand name change and the result is "Cru", which just leads the listener to ask, "what does that mean?". (facepalm)
- professionalism is sometimes not very.  staff in the regional offices are not necessarily in the roles because they were trained or experienced in accounting, event planning, operations, management, etc.  there's an admirable 'have faith & courage and figure it out" attitude.  people get promoted because of their faith and friendships more than because of their expertise.
- Cru could be described as industrialized Christianity.  There is a big emphasis on conversion numbers for staff.  Campus staff are in sales and develop sales pitches.  
- forgetting to get out of Cru can be a career disaster.  many times dads will say to young staff "do this for a while if you must".  and, I'd say after 14 years, that this is good advice.  after a few years, go get a real job.  If you decide at 35 or 40 (with multiple kids and no marketable skills) that you want to transition, it will be tough.

review_title: Lack of Adequate Compensation & Expected to Fit In a Box Theologically
pros: The people you work for & with at Cru generally care about you and your wellbeing. Most workers are at the ministry because they care about what they do . The health benefits are good and you have an adequate work life balance. Opportunities for personal growth through yearly reviews and personality development activities as teams.  Beautiful headquarters and nice working conditions. Supervisors and Leaders are supportive and encouraging.
cons:
A very apparent lack of opportunity for advancement for hourly administrative staff. You are hired at a certain pay and job level and it is very hard to grow except for small incremental dollar or less an hour raises yearly. Many higher up jobs are reserved for  missionaries that raise their salaries. I saw many very talented, passionate people working in the same administrative roles for years, capable of doing much more but were in the same job since opportunity to become a team leader or grow in responsibility was not very accessible. The level of work done and asked for is not compensated fairly. You are asked to be spiritually, emotionally and professionally invested yet that is hard to do when you could make 4 or 5 dollars an hour more at another company doing the same job. 

Working at Cru is also very hard if you don't fit perfectly into the evangelical mould. If you don't identify as a conservative, evangelical Christian and have differing views, you may be the minority. Speakers brought in and devotions read tend to display a very similar experience and set of beliefs. I guess this is what you sign on for though when you sign a strict statement of faith. Cru needs to work on diversity and respecting that there may be more than one way of looking at a theological topic. pros:
Cru does go above and beyond in personal development, emotional care, and team dynamics. If you have a great team at your campus/metro area, you will feel the most valued and cared for than you will probably in any other job. 

People on here complaining about the money make me raise an eyebrow, because I don't know what person would go into campus staff looking for that in particular. There are salary caps, but it is within your power to at least take the steps to raise more support if that's what you want (obviously can't make people give, but you can certainly try). Your work can be hard to quantify, and it can be hard to measure how things are going because many of your objectives are intangible, but ultimately what you do can change lives. 

Cru is taking a lot of steps to increase diversity in leadership and supporting more cross-cultural ministry skills within the U.S. campus, which is a welcome shift. Our students can feel the difference.
cons:
As good as it is to have a great team, having one where people don't feel like natural friends or one where people can't resolve conflict is a total morale killer. I am thankful that this isn't my situation, but it makes me sad to have friends who feel totally isolated from the rest of their team or don't feel listened to. 

A lot of what Cru offers is great for families, maybe at the expense of single or childless staff couples. Our required regional conference has been at a water park hotel in a remote part of the state with nothing to do if you aren't interested in eating pizza and lying in a lazy river with a bunch of kids running around. (This is all going away soon but has just been my experience thus far.) Wives' day might have been more necessary when Cru began and women tended to do most of the housework, but even as a married woman myself, it seems unfair to give me a whole day to do whatever I want when my husband helps out with his share of our household tasks while single people have to do it all on the weekend (when you aren't already working on the weekend). 

There are a lot of required conferences that seem expensive for what you get; it can feel like being forced to pay money to be forced to "recharge." 

Many of the current organizational changes happening aren't bad, per se, but the way they are being communicated can be confusing and isolating. I don't think that's the intent at all, which is a bummer. But I think there's a generational disconnect, and it will tie back to types of teams -- I like the idea of being more catalytic and sending people where there's a need, but I also really would hate to send my prize students off into the intern lotto machine and have them dropped somewhere alone with a team that doesn't get along the way ours does. I also think the big vision currently being presented about doing more and reaching more wears out metro campus teams who are already spread thin -- maybe a traditional university's Cru movement will have the capacity to add high schools or other new target areas, but for a movement already on a bunch of schools without being acknowledged for being on that level already, it feels like more guilt and pressure to be even busier. I am nervous certain people and teams will be brought to total burnout.
